samples.code:
<$script> export let data-testid; $state text = ""; function countWords(str) { if (str.trim() === "") return 0; return str.trim().split(/\s+/).length; } function countChars(str) { return str.length; } $derived.by text ([input]) => { let wordCount = countWords(input); let charCount = countChars(input); let isLong = wordCount > 15; return { wordCount, charCount, isLong }; };

Words: {$derived.by.text.wordCount}

Characters: {$derived.by.text.charCount}

Status: {$derived.by.text.isLong ? 'Long text' : 'Short text'}

samples.code:
$text = event.target.value } />

Words: {window.derived.wordCount}

Characters: {window.derived.charCount}

Status: {window.derived.isLong ? 'Long text' : 'Short text'}

This component: 1. Creates a stateful text variable using $state 2. Uses $derived.by to create derived values based on text 3. Calculates word count, character count, and long/short status in the via function 4. Subscribes to the derived values and stores them in the window for access in the template 5. Binds the input field to the text state with debounce for better performance 6. Updates the displayed values using the derived state from the window 7. Includes a "Clear" button to reset the text The debounce modifier ensures we don't update the state too frequently, and the via function performs the necessary calculations. The derived values are then accessed via the window object since Svelte 5's reactive scoping might not allow direct access in the template.

Words: {$derived.wordCount}

Characters: {$derived.charCount}

Status: { $derived.isLong ? 'Long text' : 'Short text' }

Hello, World!

This Svelte component: 1. Uses $state to create a reactive text variable initialized to "Hello world" 2. Uses $inspect(text).with(...) to log updates to the input value with a custom callback 3. Uses $effect to run $inspect.trace(text) whenever the input changes, which helps track the reactive dependencies 4. Calculates the character count using a derived value charCount that depends on text 5. Binds the input field value to text 6. Displays the text value and character count with appropriate data test IDs The $inspect rune is used both directly with .with() for custom callbacks and inside an effect with .trace() to ensure proper reactive tracking.

Hello, {$props.name}!

Count: {internalCount}

{#if $props.showDetails}

Name is {$props.name}

Count is {internalCount}

ShowDetails is {$props.showDetails}

{/if}

Hello, {$props.name}!

Count: {$count}

{#if $props.showDetails}

Name is {$props.name}

Count is {$count}

ShowDetails is {String($props.showDetails)}

{/if}

Hello, {$props.name}!

Count: {countState}

{#if $props.showDetails}

Name is {$props.name}

Count is {countState}

ShowDetails is {$props.showDetails}

{/if}
This Svelte 5 component: 1. Defines the required props with default values using the $props rune 2. Creates a reactive countState variable using $state that's initialized from the count prop 3. Displays the name in a heading with the test ID 4. Shows the current count from countState 5. Has a button to increment the count state 6. Conditionally renders the details div when showDetails is true 7. Includes all required data test IDs for testing The component uses Svelte 5's new runes syntax ($props, $state) and reactive updates through the $state variable. The initial count from props is used to initialize the state, but the component's count is then controlled by the local state variable.

Hello, {$props.name}!

{#if $props.showDetails}

Count is {stateCount}

ShowDetails is {String($props.showDetails)}

{/if}

Hello, {$name}!

Count: {$localCount}

{#if $showDetails}

Name is {$name}

Count is {$localCount}

ShowDetails is {$showDetails}

{/if}

Hello, {$props.name}!

Count: {counter}

{#if $props.showDetails}

Name is {$props.name}

Count is {counter}

ShowDetails is {$props.showDetails}

{/if}
